Award.AwardTitle: Technological Literacy: Assessment and Measurement of Learning Gains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This effort is conducting a workshop to create a broad-based characterization & measurement of the technological literacy of American undergraduates and the potential effectiveness of technological literacy courses. The workshop is utilizing and refining existing assessment tools to: 1) measure increases in technological literacy for undergraduates; 2) develop new shared assessment tools & related standard learning outcomes; 3) investigate how increased technological literacy impacts actions & attitudes; and 4) identify factors that promote the institutionalization of technological literacy courses. The combined results will help create a means to characterize and measure the technological literacy of American undergraduates and gauge the potential effectiveness of technological literacy courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project conducted work to develop methods to assess and measure what undergraduate students that are not specifically studying science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) know about technological concepts and engineering. America’s standard of living and way of life depend upon technology. It is vital both for both empowerment of the individual and national economic growth that informed citizens have an understanding of what technology is, how it works, how it is created, and how society influences technological development.  Since assessments of engineering students typically emphasize mathematics, other approaches are needed for non-engineers.

The intellectual merit of this work is found in the refinement of definitions of engineering and technological literacy, development, and testing of a framework for an engineering reasoning assessment, determination of what competencies non-engineers would like regarding engineering and technology, and identification of factors that help faculty members to offer courses on engineering and technology.

The project combined the efforts of a number of engineering faculty members that taught courses on engineering literacy.  A workshop was conducted to utilize and refine the existing assessments used by individual faculty into assessment tools that could be broadly applied. The project also utilized the collective experience of faculty to begin to develop methods to detect and measure how increased technological literacy impacts the actions and attitudes of individuals in their daily life.

Project work first focused on clarifying definitions of engineering and technological literacy. Engineering literacy was viewed as having a focus directed more toward the process of creating or designing technological artifacts or systems. Technological literacy includes a broader view of the products or results of the engineering process as well as the relation between technology and society.

The project developed a concise set of core ideas that encompass the essential dimensions of engineering and technology. Ten main principles were developed to serve as the core ideas describing the structure or nature of technological systems. The framework starts with the concept of function and extends through the design process and technological evolution. This framework is not dependent on any one specific type of technology and can be used to address higher order thinking rather than simple recall of specific facts or repetition of rote procedures. An important feature of this set is possession of sufficient generality to be able to include the range of specific technologies, scientific principles, and engineering topics that may occur within an individual course.

Major ideas include the following: technological systems are created to achieve a function that is accomplished through physical form. Technological systems transform materials, energy, and information. Function is provided by components combined into systems. Components utilize physical phenomena which can be modeled using mathematics. Systems employ diverse interacting phenomena. Component functions transfer across systems. Systems can become components in other systems and systems are sociotechnical. System design creates component ensembles with emergent properties. Technological system domains are groups of systems related to a set of shared component types and underlying physical principles. Technological systems evolve often by a process of substitution at the component and subsystem level.  A set of pilot questions was developed and tested with a range of undergraduate students across multiple institution types.

Work on the impact of engineering literacy on the daily lives of non-engineers revealed a number of areas of increased empowerment in the relation of non-engineers with everyday technology. Non-engineers noted that taking a course in engineering and technological literacy improved their own problem-solving around technological issues and helped them to be more confident in talking with service people about problems associated with technology such as cars or computers. These results are significant in showing that non-engineers see the ability to troubleshoot and solve technological problems as more important than understanding the engineering design process.

Undergraduate faculty that have successfully offered engineering literacy courses cite the need to fulfill a general education graduation requirement as the most important factor in successful institutionalization. However, considerable variation exists on the specific requirement met by the various engineering and technological literacy requirement. While a laboratory or science-type requirement is common, some engineering literacy courses are structured to as first-year seminars or honors courses. Some are able to fulfill writing requirements.

The broader impacts of this project stem from improving the ability of undergraduate educators to contribute to the development of a technically literate citizenry.  More readily available and generalized assessment tools will raise the quality of instruction and increase the scale of efforts to improve the understanding of a wide-range of technological devices, processes, and systems. Education on engineering and technological literacy for all undergraduates has the potential to improve the understanding of technology by all students and develop in all students the ways of thinking seen as vital to the future of the American technologically-based economy.
